I believe the blur youre inferring should be there is assumed based on your understanding of photography and the cameras depth of field. That "blur" isn't "real" but simply a aspect which can be modified by adjusting the cameras aperture and exposure time to make everything "crisp"

As for your stars. I feel like you could do a could things.
1) Ink it up how you did, then kinda mono type the stars by going in and overwiping dots in with like a fine q tip or a rag pulled around a pencil or something.
2) burnish some spots to lighten them up.
3) maybe do a chine-colle
4) etc

Yah, honestly, layering/ and using transparent inks take time to get used to, but you'll save you a lot of time if you keep making multicolor prints. I always say i'm a lazy printmaker, so i try to take every shortcut (within reason) to save myself time. work smart, not hard

Looks nice. It might make your life easier if you work with transparent inks and overlapping to get just as many colors with less screens. (red+yellow=orange/ blue+yellow=green). If you look at the work of Jay Ryan (the bird machine) he gets so many colors outta 2-3 color layers, split fountains and overlapping. Just a thought. Anyway your print looks nice

No worries, was just wondering what hyper subtle litho element you included :)

Yip, its a 4 separate plates. basically its instead of etching a stone, i draw on a transparency, then expose that to a photosensitive plate, and print each layer just like lithography.

I've been working with litho for about the past year, specifically photo lithography. I always describe them as photolithos but if someone's calls them lithos I don't mind, since it's basically the same end result, you just just use all the chemicals. I mean many of my favorite lithographer (such as ericka walker Michael Barnes) often use plate litho
And I guess outa any process I think I hear various prints called silk screens more than anything else.
I mean if some "casual"(nonprontmaker) called a dollar bill an intaglio, I'd be more excited that they "basically" got it right instead of being upset that they don't fully understand the our specialized vocabulary.

sorry i don't mean to discourage you... i simply want you to follow your dreams responsibly

Like the other comment said, make what you like. If you get into the art world/ market thinking you need to sell art in order to be "successful" and it doesn't take off, your going to have a bad time. If you make what you love and if people appreciate it, and want to buy it, great. If not your still improving and doing something you like.
I'd recommend looking for smaller art/ vendor fairs, (not the big $300 art fairs) and just taking some work out. Even if you dont sell anything it's a great way to get out and have people talk to you about what you are doing, and if you sell, great! Idk my first booth was at a free street fair, and I talked to like 50+ people, sold some stuff, but those conversations/ people being genuinely interested was almost more encouraging than sales.... I mean money is good, and keeps a roof over my head, but idk I'd often rather bullshit with someone for 20 minutes about art/whatever than have someone walk into my booth, say " that matches my living room, I'll buy it"
Follow your passion (responsibility) and let the rest sort itself out.

A lot of things could be leading to this. We have no idea if these are made with a press, or by hand, what type of ink you use, and thus it's kinda hard to give you a blanket "do this" to solve everything.
Possible solutions: More ink Different ink More pressure Even out the pressure Add some miracle gel Add a bit of oil Print with felts Print with felts and a board Etc etc

No idea, but as far as the " it won't stick" argument, yes it's true. BUT if you coat it with some form of clear coat after you print, you should be fine.

So this looks really clean on the internet, id be interested to see it in person, and how the ink sits on the image. I feel like you might get some pushback from the traditional print community for kinda "cheating" with your color, but as long as your upfront about it I think you'll be ok.
Anyway looks nice.
